page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

rev.diff:
Line 26: Line 26:
===26 January===
===26 January===
â
On 26 January riots continued. Protesters numbered in the thousands, although no accurate estimate was available. Violence by both protesters and police increased. One protester and one police official were killed in Cairo.<ref name="np26jan" /> Suez experienced a dramatic uprising; many protesters faced live rounds, and both protesters and police were beaten. Suez protesters set fire to several government buildings, including the police station.<ref name="np26jan">{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalpost.com/news/world/More+casualties+protests+escalate+Egypt/4173057/story.html|title=More Casualties as Protests Escalate in Egypt|work=[[National Post]]|date=22 December 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="aljazeera-448">{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112734210243448.html|title=Protesters Torch Egypt Police post|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=27 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112617427113878.html|title=Clinton Calls for reform in Egypt|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
+
On 26 January riots continued. Protesters numbered in the thousands, although no accurate estimate was available. Violence by both protesters and police increased. One protester and one police official were killed in Cairo.<ref name="np26jan" /> Suez experienced a dramatic uprising; many protesters faced live rounds, and both protesters and police were beaten. Suez protesters set fire to several government buildings, including the police station.<ref name="np26jan">http://article.wn.com/view/2011/01/26/More_casualties_as_protests_escalate_in_Egypt/</ref><ref name="aljazeera-448">{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112734210243448.html|title=Protesters Torch Egypt Police post|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=27 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112617427113878.html|title=Clinton Calls for reform in Egypt|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
===27 January===
===27 January===
Line 65: Line 65:
[[File:NDP HQ on fire.jpg|thumb|left|The main headquarters of the ruling [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] aflame during ''Friday of Anger'' in Cairo]]
[[File:NDP HQ on fire.jpg|thumb|left|The main headquarters of the ruling [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] aflame during ''Friday of Anger'' in Cairo]]
â
Amid reports of looting, concerns were raised about the safety of the antiquities of the famous [[Egyptian Museum]], near the epicenter of the Cairo protests. Egyptian state television announced in the evening that army commandos had secured the museum.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Egypt Army Secures Museum with Pharaonic Treasures|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/28/arts-us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70R7K820110128|work=[[Reuters]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Protesters joined soldiers in protecting the museum, situated beside the burning ruling party headquarters.<ref name="AlJazeera29th1pm">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/29/live-blog-291-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Jan 29 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=4 January 2011}}</ref> Looters managed to enter during the night from the roof to damage a number of small artifacts, and it was initially reported that they had ripped the heads off two mummies, but subsequent reports claimed that Egypt's top archaeologist had mistaken skulls from other skeletons, and that the mummies were intact.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Looters Destroy Mummies in Egyptian Museum|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70S1YU20110129|work=[[Reuters]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011|first=Yasmine|last=Saleh}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110201/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt_protest_antiquities |title=AP Interview: Egypt declares treasures safe - Yahoo! News |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2011-04-08}}. News.yahoo.com. Retrieved on 2011-04-08.</ref>
+
Amid reports of looting, concerns were raised about the safety of the antiquities of the famous [[Egyptian Museum]], near the epicenter of the Cairo protests. Egyptian state television announced in the evening that army commandos had secured the museum.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Egypt Army Secures Museum with Pharaonic Treasures|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/28/arts-us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70R7K820110128|work=[[Reuters]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Protesters joined soldiers in protecting the museum, situated beside the burning ruling party headquarters.<ref name="AlJazeera29th1pm">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/29/live-blog-291-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Jan 29 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=4 January 2011}}</ref> Looters managed to enter during the night from the roof to damage a number of small artifacts, and it was initially reported that they had ripped the heads off two mummies, but subsequent reports claimed that Egypt's top archaeologist had mistaken skulls from other skeletons, and that the mummies were intact.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Looters Destroy Mummies in Egyptian Museum|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70S1YU20110129|work=[[Reuters]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011|first=Yasmine|last=Saleh}}</ref><ref>http://www.buffalonews.com/wire-feeds/24-hour-world-news/article329931.ece</ref>
ElBaradei's detention prompted the U.S. to review its $1.5 billion aid package for Egypt; he was later released.<ref name="G01" /> The day's defiance was summed up by the plethora of [[Tunisia]]n national flags and anti-Mubarak [[graffiti]] that the protesters had created in the [[Greater Cairo]] region, Alexandria, Beni Suef, Mansoura and Manufiya.<ref name="chron1" /> Meanwhile, the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] said that twenty members of the banned group had been detained overnight, including Essam El-Erian, its main spokesman, and Mohammed Moursi, one of its leaders.<ref name="aljazeera2" />
ElBaradei's detention prompted the U.S. to review its $1.5 billion aid package for Egypt; he was later released.<ref name="G01" /> The day's defiance was summed up by the plethora of [[Tunisia]]n national flags and anti-Mubarak [[graffiti]] that the protesters had created in the [[Greater Cairo]] region, Alexandria, Beni Suef, Mansoura and Manufiya.<ref name="chron1" /> Meanwhile, the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] said that twenty members of the banned group had been detained overnight, including Essam El-Erian, its main spokesman, and Mohammed Moursi, one of its leaders.<ref name="aljazeera2" />
Line 166: Line 166:
The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] sent many people to show support for Mubarak.<ref>{{cite news|author=Walt, Vivienne|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2045328_2045333_2045720,00.html |title=Bloodshed as Mubarak Supporters Clash with Cairo Protesters â The Middle East in Revolt |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date= 31 January 2011|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> Provocateurs on horses and camels armed with swords, whips, clubs, stones, rocks, and pocket knives, attacked anti-government protesters in central Cairo,<ref>Ackerman, Spencer (2 February 2011). [http://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/02/horses-camels-rocks-molotovs-egypts-thug-tech/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+WiredDangerRoom+%28Blog+-+Danger+Room%29 "Horses, Camels, Rocks, Molotovs: Egypt's Thug Tech"] ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Mubarak Supporters, Protesters Clash in Egypt|author=|work=[[MSNBC]]|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41383377/ns/world_news-mideast/n_africa/|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Clashes Erupt in Cairo Between Mubarak's Allies and Foes|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/03/world/middleeast/03egypt.html|accessdate=2 February 2011|first1=David D.|last1=Kirkpatrick|first2=Kareem|last2=Fahim}}</ref> including Tahrir Square<ref>{{Cite video|date=2 February 2011|title=Camels & Horses Storm into Tahrir Square as Protesters Clash in Cairo|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXwKqmDmuDs|work=[[RT (TV network)|RT]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> in what was later known as the (''Battle of Jamal'' or ''Battle of the Camel'')<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12369422|title=Egyptian media: State misinformation amid the protests?|work=[[BBC News]]|date=4 February 2011|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|ÙÙÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙÙ}}).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.shorouknews.com/ContentData.aspx?id=384976|title=Ø¨ÙØ§ÙØ§ (ÙÙÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙÙ) ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØªØ­Ù Ø§ÙÙØµØ±Ù Ø§ÙØ¬Ø¯ÙØ¯|work=Shorouk News|date=4 February 2011|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> Security officials were witnessed bribing ordinary citizens into attacking protesters.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" /> Some pro-Mubarak supporters were reportedly off-duty and [[undercover]] police,<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who Are the Pro-Mubarak Demonstrators? |work=[[CNN]] |date= 2 February 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> carrying police IDs. Gunfire was heard in Tahrir Square.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" />
The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] sent many people to show support for Mubarak.<ref>{{cite news|author=Walt, Vivienne|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2045328_2045333_2045720,00.html |title=Bloodshed as Mubarak Supporters Clash with Cairo Protesters â The Middle East in Revolt |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date= 31 January 2011|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> Provocateurs on horses and camels armed with swords, whips, clubs, stones, rocks, and pocket knives, attacked anti-government protesters in central Cairo,<ref>Ackerman, Spencer (2 February 2011). [http://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/02/horses-camels-rocks-molotovs-egypts-thug-tech/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+WiredDangerRoom+%28Blog+-+Danger+Room%29 "Horses, Camels, Rocks, Molotovs: Egypt's Thug Tech"] ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Mubarak Supporters, Protesters Clash in Egypt|author=|work=[[MSNBC]]|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41383377/ns/world_news-mideast/n_africa/|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Clashes Erupt in Cairo Between Mubarak's Allies and Foes|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/03/world/middleeast/03egypt.html|accessdate=2 February 2011|first1=David D.|last1=Kirkpatrick|first2=Kareem|last2=Fahim}}</ref> including Tahrir Square<ref>{{Cite video|date=2 February 2011|title=Camels & Horses Storm into Tahrir Square as Protesters Clash in Cairo|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXwKqmDmuDs|work=[[RT (TV network)|RT]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> in what was later known as the (''Battle of Jamal'' or ''Battle of the Camel'')<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12369422|title=Egyptian media: State misinformation amid the protests?|work=[[BBC News]]|date=4 February 2011|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|ÙÙÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙÙ}}).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.shorouknews.com/ContentData.aspx?id=384976|title=Ø¨ÙØ§ÙØ§ (ÙÙÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙÙ) ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØªØ­Ù Ø§ÙÙØµØ±Ù Ø§ÙØ¬Ø¯ÙØ¯|work=Shorouk News|date=4 February 2011|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> Security officials were witnessed bribing ordinary citizens into attacking protesters.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" /> Some pro-Mubarak supporters were reportedly off-duty and [[undercover]] police,<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who Are the Pro-Mubarak Demonstrators? |work=[[CNN]] |date= 2 February 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> carrying police IDs. Gunfire was heard in Tahrir Square.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" />
â
[[Molotov cocktails]] were also used on protesters,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110202/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt |title=Chaos in Cairo as Mubarak Backers, Opponents Clash|work=[[Yahoo! News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> some landing on the grounds of the [[Egyptian Museum]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/02/egypt-protests-live-updates#block-66 |title=Egypt protests - Wednesday 2 February |work=The Guardian |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=4 February 2011 |location=London |first1=Matthew |last1=Weaver |first2=Haroon |last2=Siddique |first3=Richard |last3=Adams |first4=Paul |last4=Owen}}</ref> Pro-Mubarak supporters were filmed dropping stones and firebombs from buildings onto demonstrators. Five were reported killed and 836 were taken to hospitals according the Health Minister.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/world/67633/five-dead-as-shots-fired-during-cairo-clashes |title=Five Dead as Shots Fired During Cairo Clashes |work=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> There were also clashes in Alexandria<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12345656 |title=Egypt Unrest: Deadly Clashes Rock Cairo's Tahrir Square |work=[[BBC News]] |date= 2 February 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and unrest in Port Said.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" /> Anaylsts suggested a strategy of "hired muscle" had repeatedly been employed in the past by the Mubarak regime, suggesting the same approach was possible. The Interior Ministry denied that this was being done.<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who Are the Pro-Mubarak Demonstrators?|work=[[CNN]]|date= 2 February 2011|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
+
[[Molotov cocktails]] were also used on protesters,<ref>http://www.myfoxatlanta.com/dpp/news/chaos-in-cairo-as-mubarak-backers-opponents-clash-020211</ref> some landing on the grounds of the [[Egyptian Museum]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/02/egypt-protests-live-updates#block-66 |title=Egypt protests - Wednesday 2 February |work=The Guardian |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=4 February 2011 |location=London |first1=Matthew |last1=Weaver |first2=Haroon |last2=Siddique |first3=Richard |last3=Adams |first4=Paul |last4=Owen}}</ref> Pro-Mubarak supporters were filmed dropping stones and firebombs from buildings onto demonstrators. Five were reported killed and 836 were taken to hospitals according the Health Minister.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/world/67633/five-dead-as-shots-fired-during-cairo-clashes |title=Five Dead as Shots Fired During Cairo Clashes |work=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> There were also clashes in Alexandria<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12345656 |title=Egypt Unrest: Deadly Clashes Rock Cairo's Tahrir Square |work=[[BBC News]] |date= 2 February 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and unrest in Port Said.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" /> Anaylsts suggested a strategy of "hired muscle" had repeatedly been employed in the past by the Mubarak regime, suggesting the same approach was possible. The Interior Ministry denied that this was being done.<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who Are the Pro-Mubarak Demonstrators?|work=[[CNN]]|date= 2 February 2011|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
Some journalists were attacked by the pro-Mubarak activists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/02/anderson-cooper-attacked-punched-egypt_n_817352.html |title=Anderson Cooper Attacked, Punched in the Head by Pro-Mubarak Mob in Egypt |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8288167/Egypt-protests-live.html |title=Egypt Protests: Live |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011 |location=London |first=Amy |last=Willis}}</ref> Western media suggested the possibility of civil war as violence between the two sides escalated, leaving over a thousand injured.<ref>Beaumont, Peter; Shenker, Jack. [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/03/egyptian-army-disperses-mubarak-supporters "Egyptian Army Disperses Mubarak Supporters from Bridge"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Crisis-Violence-Breaks-Out-Between-Pro-And-Anti-Mubarak-Supporters-In-Tahrir-Square-Cairo/Article/201102115920969?lpos=World_News_Carousel_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_15920969_Egypt_Crisis%3A_Violence_Breaks_Out_Between_Pro_And_Anti-Mubarak_Supporters_In_Tahrir_Square%2C_Cairo |title=Egypt Crisis: Violence Breaks Out Between Pro And Anti-Mubarak Supporters In Tahrir Square, Cairo |work=[[Sky News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4023068,00.html |title=Civil War Underway in Egypt?|work=[[Ynetnews]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>Al-Shalchi, Hadeel; El Deeb, Sarah (2 February 2011). [http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/latest-news/hundreds-injured-one-dead-after-mubarak-protesters-and-supporters-clash/article1891913/page2/ "Hundreds Injured, One Dead after Mubarak Protesters and Supporters Clash"]. ''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[The Globe and Mail]]''). Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2011/02/02/egypt-mubarak-military.html "Egyptian Clashes Leave 3 Dead, Hundreds Hurt â Demonstrations Continue in Cairo Despite Curfew"]. 2 February 2011''[[CBC News]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref>
Some journalists were attacked by the pro-Mubarak activists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/02/anderson-cooper-attacked-punched-egypt_n_817352.html |title=Anderson Cooper Attacked, Punched in the Head by Pro-Mubarak Mob in Egypt |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8288167/Egypt-protests-live.html |title=Egypt Protests: Live |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011 |location=London |first=Amy |last=Willis}}</ref> Western media suggested the possibility of civil war as violence between the two sides escalated, leaving over a thousand injured.<ref>Beaumont, Peter; Shenker, Jack. [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/03/egyptian-army-disperses-mubarak-supporters "Egyptian Army Disperses Mubarak Supporters from Bridge"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Crisis-Violence-Breaks-Out-Between-Pro-And-Anti-Mubarak-Supporters-In-Tahrir-Square-Cairo/Article/201102115920969?lpos=World_News_Carousel_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_15920969_Egypt_Crisis%3A_Violence_Breaks_Out_Between_Pro_And_Anti-Mubarak_Supporters_In_Tahrir_Square%2C_Cairo |title=Egypt Crisis: Violence Breaks Out Between Pro And Anti-Mubarak Supporters In Tahrir Square, Cairo |work=[[Sky News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4023068,00.html |title=Civil War Underway in Egypt?|work=[[Ynetnews]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>Al-Shalchi, Hadeel; El Deeb, Sarah (2 February 2011). [http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/latest-news/hundreds-injured-one-dead-after-mubarak-protesters-and-supporters-clash/article1891913/page2/ "Hundreds Injured, One Dead after Mubarak Protesters and Supporters Clash"]. ''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[The Globe and Mail]]''). Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2011/02/02/egypt-mubarak-military.html "Egyptian Clashes Leave 3 Dead, Hundreds Hurt â Demonstrations Continue in Cairo Despite Curfew"]. 2 February 2011''[[CBC News]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref>
Line 315: Line 315:
===10 February===
===10 February===
[[File:Tahrir Square - February 10, 2011.png|thumb|Over 2 millions protesting in [[Tahrir Square]] on February 10, 2011 after [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s speech saying that they'll go to his palace the day after.]]
[[File:Tahrir Square - February 10, 2011.png|thumb|Over 2 millions protesting in [[Tahrir Square]] on February 10, 2011 after [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s speech saying that they'll go to his palace the day after.]]
â
The protests continued at Tahrir Square and the parliament building. 3,000 lawyers marched from the lawyers' syndicate in downtown Cairo to [[Abdeen Palace]], one of Mubarak's official residences. About a thousand physicians, dressed in white coats, also arrived at Tahrir Square to applause.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/09/live-blog-feb-10-egypt-protests|title=Live Blog Feb 10 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref> Strikes at national industries, including tourism and transportation, continued and spread to Alexandria, Mahalla and Port Said.<ref name="VOA-20110210">{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Protests-Strikes-Spread-as-Egypts-Regime-Stiffens-115706904.html|title=Protests, Strikes Spread as Egypt's Regime Stiffens|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=February 10, 2011}}</ref> Protesters around Egypt, expecting Mubarak's resignation, were described as euphoric, while singing and waving Egyptian flags.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110210/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt_protest_scene_1 |title=Expecting Mubarak to go, protest camp euphoric - Yahoo! News |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2011-04-08}}. News.yahoo.com (2011-02-11). Retrieved on 2011-04-08.</ref> Fighter aircraft were heard above the Tahrir Square at 20:00 amid calls for the "destruction of the regime." In Alexandria, over 1,000 "diehard" protesters were reported by the train station.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/10/live-blog-feb-10-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 10 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>
+
The protests continued at Tahrir Square and the parliament building. 3,000 lawyers marched from the lawyers' syndicate in downtown Cairo to [[Abdeen Palace]], one of Mubarak's official residences. About a thousand physicians, dressed in white coats, also arrived at Tahrir Square to applause.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/09/live-blog-feb-10-egypt-protests|title=Live Blog Feb 10 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref> Strikes at national industries, including tourism and transportation, continued and spread to Alexandria, Mahalla and Port Said.<ref name="VOA-20110210">{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Protests-Strikes-Spread-as-Egypts-Regime-Stiffens-115706904.html|title=Protests, Strikes Spread as Egypt's Regime Stiffens|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=February 10, 2011}}</ref> Protesters around Egypt, expecting Mubarak's resignation, were described as euphoric, while singing and waving Egyptian flags.<ref>http://www.buffalonews.com/wire-feeds/24-hour-world-news/article338025.ece</ref> Fighter aircraft were heard above the Tahrir Square at 20:00 amid calls for the "destruction of the regime." In Alexandria, over 1,000 "diehard" protesters were reported by the train station.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/10/live-blog-feb-10-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 10 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>
Prior to Mubarak's speech, contradictory reports from various media sources around the world stated that either Suleiman or Tantawi was expected to take over.<ref>[http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000622357 ××¦×¨×× ×××¨× ×××©××¨ ×¦×××? ×××××¨×§ ×¦×¤×× ×××ª×¤××¨ ××¢×¨×],Israel's [[Globes]] newspaper, 2 February 2011</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Fam |first=Mariam |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-10/mubarak-may-resign-before-september-egyptian-ruling-party-official-says.html |title=Egypt's President Mubarak May Step Down as Army Meets |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> The military council also met without Mubarak.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb" /> The Muslim Brotherhood had feared a coup at one point. The head of the NDP said that Mubarak should go for the good of the country.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb" />
Prior to Mubarak's speech, contradictory reports from various media sources around the world stated that either Suleiman or Tantawi was expected to take over.<ref>[http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000622357 ××¦×¨×× ×××¨× ×××©××¨ ×¦×××? ×××××¨×§ ×¦×¤×× ×××ª×¤××¨ ××¢×¨×],Israel's [[Globes]] newspaper, 2 February 2011</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Fam |first=Mariam |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-10/mubarak-may-resign-before-september-egyptian-ruling-party-official-says.html |title=Egypt's President Mubarak May Step Down as Army Meets |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> The military council also met without Mubarak.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb" /> The Muslim Brotherhood had feared a coup at one point. The head of the NDP said that Mubarak should go for the good of the country.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb" />
Line 327: Line 327:
In his television statement, Mubarak said that he would penalise those responsible for the violence and had a clear vision on how to end the crisis, but was satisfied with what he had offered. He stated that while remaining president to the end of his term in September he would transfer his powers to the vice-president.<ref>{{cite web|last=Shahine |first=Alaa |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-10/mubarak-ignores-calls-for-ouster-delegates-authority-to-egypt-s-suleiman.html |title=Mubarak Defiance of Ouster Calls Angers Protesters |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref><ref name=transfers/> As far as transfer of power was concerned, Mubarak said "I have seen that it is required to delegate the powers and authorities of the president to the vice president as dictated in the constitution,". The constitutional article was used to transfer powers if the president was "temporarily" unable to carry out his duties and did not require his resignation.<ref name=transfers/> He also said he would request six constitutional amendments and that he would lift emergency laws when security in the country permitted.<ref name=transfers/> Mubarak said he would stay in the country and was "adamant to continue to shoulder my responsibility to protect the constitution and safeguard the interests of the people ... until power is handed over to those elected in September by the people in free and fair elections in which all the guarantees of transparencies will be secured."<ref name=transfers/>
In his television statement, Mubarak said that he would penalise those responsible for the violence and had a clear vision on how to end the crisis, but was satisfied with what he had offered. He stated that while remaining president to the end of his term in September he would transfer his powers to the vice-president.<ref>{{cite web|last=Shahine |first=Alaa |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-10/mubarak-ignores-calls-for-ouster-delegates-authority-to-egypt-s-suleiman.html |title=Mubarak Defiance of Ouster Calls Angers Protesters |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref><ref name=transfers/> As far as transfer of power was concerned, Mubarak said "I have seen that it is required to delegate the powers and authorities of the president to the vice president as dictated in the constitution,". The constitutional article was used to transfer powers if the president was "temporarily" unable to carry out his duties and did not require his resignation.<ref name=transfers/> He also said he would request six constitutional amendments and that he would lift emergency laws when security in the country permitted.<ref name=transfers/> Mubarak said he would stay in the country and was "adamant to continue to shoulder my responsibility to protect the constitution and safeguard the interests of the people ... until power is handed over to those elected in September by the people in free and fair elections in which all the guarantees of transparencies will be secured."<ref name=transfers/>
â
Protesters watched in stunned silence or in anger to his speech, some crying or waving their shoes in the air.<ref name=transfers/> People in Tahrir Square chanted "Leave! Leave! Leave!" after Mubarak's speech.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://parkerspitzer.blogs.cnn.com/2011/02/10/mubarak-says-hes-staying-until-september/ |title=Mubarak says he's staying until September |publisher=Parker Spitzer - CNN.com Blogs |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Suleiman called on the protesters to go home.<ref name=transfers>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5RQO0.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Protesters then moved to the state television and radio buildings.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb" /> Soon after the television announcement, a large number of protesters began to march towards the presidential palace.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110210-719857.html |title=2nd UPDATE: Oil Gains; Stocks, Euro Fall; Mostly Calm On Egypt News - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date= 10 February 2011|accessdate=2011-02-11}} {{Dead link|date=May 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> ElBaradei said, "Egypt will explode" because Mubarak refused to step down and called on the military to intervene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA71380.html |title=ElBaradei calls on Egyptian army to intervene |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
+
Protesters watched in stunned silence or in anger to his speech, some crying or waving their shoes in the air.<ref name=transfers/> People in Tahrir Square chanted "Leave! Leave! Leave!" after Mubarak's speech.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://parkerspitzer.blogs.cnn.com/2011/02/10/mubarak-says-hes-staying-until-september/ |title=Mubarak says he's staying until September |publisher=Parker Spitzer - CNN.com Blogs |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Suleiman called on the protesters to go home.<ref name=transfers>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5RQO0.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Protesters then moved to the state television and radio buildings.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb" /> Soon after the television announcement, a large number of protesters began to march towards the presidential palace.<ref>http://www.vindianz.com/business/oil-gains-stocks-euro-fall-mostly-calm-on-egypt-news-wall-street-journal-041301.html</ref> ElBaradei said, "Egypt will explode" because Mubarak refused to step down and called on the military to intervene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA71380.html |title=ElBaradei calls on Egyptian army to intervene |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
Mubarak's top aides, family and son Gamal told him he could ride out the turmoil, which convinced him to cling to power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110212/D9LBGH2O0.html |title=Mubarak's final hours: Desperate bids to stay |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> It was also reported that one son, Alaa, accused his younger brother Gamal of ruining their father's reputation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sabel |first=Robbie |url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=208106 |title='Mubarak's sons nearly come to blows during speech' |publisher=Jpost.com |date=2011-02-14 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/13/us-egypt-mubarak-sons-idUSTRE71C26L20110213 |title=Sons of Egypt's Mubarak nearly came to blows: report |publisher= |date= 13 February 2011|accessdate=2011-04-08 |work=Reuters |first=Andrew |last=Hammond}}. Reuters. Retrieved on 2011-04-08.</ref> Eyewitnesses said that the Egyptian army had pulled out troops from many locations near the presidential palace.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/315254 |title=Witnesses: Egyptian army withdraws from positions near presidential palace |publisher=Almasryalyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>

Line 346: Line 346:
Mubarak's resignation was followed by nationwide celebrations.<ref name="ahram1"/> ElBaradei told the ''Associated Press'' "This is the greatest day of my life. The country has been liberated after decades of repression," and he expected a "beautiful" transition of power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110211/D9LAM4LO0.html |title=Mubarak resigns, hands power to military |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Mohammed ElBaradei said that "Egypt is free."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1618774.php/ElBaradei-Egypt-is-a-free-and-proud-nation-Extra |title=ElBaradei: Egypt is a free and proud nation (Extra) |publisher=Monsters and Critics |date=2010-11-17 |accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref> Various media outlets pointed out that this date was also the anniversary of the Iranian [[Islamic Revolution]], which occurred on 11 February 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/news/iran-congratulates-egyptian-people-s-victory-news-international-lcmcacigiid.html |title=Iran congratulates Egyptian people's 'victory' |publisher=Sify.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref>

An [[exchange traded fund]] based on the Egyptian stock market listed at the [[NYSE Euronext]] increased by 5% following the announcement. Egyptian five-year [[credit default swaps]] fell by 0.25%. ''Al Arabiya'' reported that the military council said it would sack the cabinet and dissolve parliament.<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" /> Celebrations and car honking were reported in Alexandria and Cairo.<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" /> Celebratory gunfire in Gaza.<ref>Karam, Zeina. (2011-02-11) [http://ca.news.yahoo.com/israeli-officials-egypts-mubarak-looking-honourable-exit-power-20110211-000625-393.html With fireworks and celebratory gunfire, festivities sweep Mideast after news of Mubarak's exit - Yahoo! News]. Ca.news.yahoo.com. Retrieved on 2011-04-08.</ref>
+
An [[exchange traded fund]] based on the Egyptian stock market listed at the [[NYSE Euronext]] increased by 5% following the announcement. Egyptian five-year [[credit default swaps]] fell by 0.25%. ''Al Arabiya'' reported that the military council said it would sack the cabinet and dissolve parliament.<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" /> Celebrations and car honking were reported in Alexandria and Cairo.<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" /> Celebratory gunfire in Gaza.<ref>http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/02/12/ap/world/main7342637.shtml</ref>
[[CBS]] correspondent [[Lara Logan]] was covering the jubilation in Tahrir Square when she suffered a brutal and sustained sexual assault and beating before being saved by a group of women and an estimated 20 Egyptian soldiers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1357485/Lara-Logan-assault-Former-GMTV-reporter-suffers-sex-attack-covering-Egypt-uprising.html |title=Ex-GMTV reporter Lara Logan leaves hospital six days after Cairo mob sex-attack - and vows to be back at work within weeks |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2011-02-16 |accessdate=2011-02-20 |location=London}}</ref>
[[CBS]] correspondent [[Lara Logan]] was covering the jubilation in Tahrir Square when she suffered a brutal and sustained sexual assault and beating before being saved by a group of women and an estimated 20 Egyptian soldiers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1357485/Lara-Logan-assault-Former-GMTV-reporter-suffers-sex-attack-covering-Egypt-uprising.html |title=Ex-GMTV reporter Lara Logan leaves hospital six days after Cairo mob sex-attack - and vows to be back at work within weeks |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2011-02-16 |accessdate=2011-02-20 |location=London}}</ref>
